Comment: The opening is relatively common so I'll refrain from annotations till later.
The opening is relatively common so I'll refrain from annotations till later.

Unfamiliar to some, but Anand navigates the position well. White has a queenside majority of pawns, and his central queen dominates the board. However Black threatens with 18...Bf6 or 18...Rd8, even 18...Nb4 is strong.

(!) Anand prepares for 19...e5 with a dominant centre. At the price of limiting his own g6-bishop, Black limits the g3-knight. Anand saw this as more important.
The potential for counterplay is visible after Anand's 20...e5 21.Bc4...
The potential for counterplay is visible after Anand's 20...e5 21.Bc4...
The potential for counterplay is visible after Anand's 20...e5 21.Bc4...
(!) Although relinquishing control of e4, note how badly placed the c1-bishop is!
(!) If 23.Qxb5? Then 23...Bxe4. If 23.axb6? Then 23...Nxb6 24.Qc2 Bxe4 25.Bxe4 Qxe4!
